title: politics jeremy corbyn party
story: Come what may, on December  our country will be led by  Boris Johnson orJeremy Corbyn,   who was aptly described by Molly Bennett, , this week as “the red man” who “doesn’t like  Jewish people”.We have been bombarded with muddied interpretations of how the tax system works, a startling lack of understanding of financial reserves and national debt, and delusion on the negative impact renationalisation would have on millions of families.So is it any wonder we are all at sixes and sevens as we head into this festive season Allow me to present my survival guide to the run-up to Christmas.If you are wondering how to stay festive when there is a General Election,  my advice is to get out and party!It might sound counter-intuitive but look at it this way: There’s nothing like a group huddle during periods of uncertainty, whether it’s to celebrate the result you hoped for, or to drown your sorrows and commiserate.So send the invites out and crack open some beers.Apart from anything , it might be the last party you can affordLabour get in.All that said, allow me to suggest caution when it comes to the office party.Whatever you do at the bash, don’t get too drunk.  Yes, I know it’s sometimes free booze. And  I understand the desire to let yourself off the leash. But it might be one of the few times you find yourself in the same room as your boss — with a chance to impress or ruin your career.You’ll be well aware we are living in the #MeToo era. And we all know, on occasions, it can go too far and that we shouldn’t all be frightened about exactly what we say and who to say it to.To allay your fears, my advice to you isyou want to dance with a colleague, ask her. If she says no then that’s your answer.Compliments are fine by the way. Us women love them , but think of your sister when giving them out.“You look great in that dress” is something you’d say to your sister, and “you look hot in that dress” isn’t.If you are looking at the month ahead and feeling overwhelmed already, this is really the only advice that you need: Start delegating.Write a list of all the jobs that need to be done and then allocate jobs to everyone over the age of ten.Getting your family to pull their weight is the best way to ensure that everyone has a happy Christmas.I know a lot of people dread the season, partly because they have to spend time with tricky in-laws.You can either not invite them  — why ruin your day   — or invite others too . Or just grin and bear it.Lastly,you are struggling with presents, please allow me to share the rules of our traditional Brady Family Christmas Present Game, played by the  members of our family on Christmas Day.Everyone buys four gts, having set a price limit: We have three at £, one at £.Wrap each one beautully so it’s impossible to distinguish premium from Primark. I once placed a roll of toilet paper with Donald Trump’s face on it in a Chanel gt bag — it was the hotly contended present everyone wanted that year . . . until they opened it.You place all gts on the table then take it in turns to throw a dice. When you get a six you pick anyone present you want . Keep throwing until all gts are distributed.Then throw six rounds with two dice and for every six you get you can pinch a present from anyone’s pile.And when it’s done you keep and open the presents you have won. It keeps us occupied for hours.I LOVED the photos of Kelly Brook in the Bahamas, where she is celebrating turning . What a great advert she is for the idea that le begins at !Kelly is naturally beautul with a big smile – and I think she looks absolutely amazing.“Lord Sugar couldn’t relate to me. That was the fundamental problem.“And I started getting that feeling from about week four.”The problem with interviews like this is that it puts her in danger of sounding a little bit like a sore loser.Oh, and also, I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but Lord Sugar doesn’t particularly like any of them at the moment.CONGRATULATIONS to builder Steve Thomson, , and his we Lenka, , who scooped the  £million EuroMillions jackpot.All their neighbours have said it couldn’t happen to a nicer couple. And I love the fact that the first thing they want to do with the money is given each of their three kids their own bedroom. This is a fairly humble ambition when you consider they are now one of the biggest British Lottery winners of all time.I also love the fact that Steve said he won’t stop working as a builder and will finish all his jobs before Christmas.He’s also already spelled out to his children thatthey want something “you’ll have to earn it”.All of which reveal an outlook that will stand him in very good stead indeed. It might just mean that he will be able to enjoy his win.The fact is money does change people. It also changes the way others see you. Most families will expect something and when they don’t get it will be angry. They will say things such as “we only want a car . . . it’s not much money for you, but would mean a lot to us”.They will expect you to share out your good fortune.My advice would be to think carefully about what to do with it before you make any rash decisions – and get a very good financial adviser.The problem with people who win a lot of money is that they often totally abandon all their values and spend, spend, spend. Let’s hope Steve and Lenka hold on to theirs.Yes, sure, I can see the temptation to magically get rid of the weight that inevitably comes when you have been, you know, growing another human being inside your body.But she only had a baby six weeks ago and,she waits a bit, she’ll probably just lose the baby weight naturally.In the meantime, yet another celeb demonstrates – and adds to – the pressure to “snap back” to their pre-pregnancy figure within weeks! Yes, your body is important but so is your mind!Six weeks after birth seems too soon to me.EVENit is true that the new Calornian craze of “butt sunning” gives you “surges of energy”, better sleep and “more creativity flowing through le”, which is what one devotee called Meagan promised on a recent Instagram post, I can’t see it catching on here.Meagan  says she has incorporated “perineum sunning” – which involves presenting the area between the anus and vulva to the sun – in to her “daily rising routine”.But talk about the sun shining out of your ar*e…what on earth must the neighbours think.ULRIKA JONSSON is on a dating app for people over   Good for her. She deserves another chance at happiness –  and at  she’s got a lot of le ahead of her.A lot of jokes are made at the expense of Ulrika’s love le and the fact she has had four kids by four men. I can’t help thinking it would be discussed in a dferent wayshe was a man.I KNOW some people are annoyed that Uber will not be granted a new licence to operate in London after repeated safety failures.But I think it’s great news. title: south western railway strike today
story: The -day walkout - throughout December - will leave  services a day delayed or cancelled on SWR services.Members of the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion will heap pain on passengers in the run-up to the Christmas holiday.The union says the the long-running dispute over guards on trains is over defence of passenger safety as commuters face a festive nightmare.But South Western Railway insists it has done everything we can and more to meet the RMTs outdated demands.Around , trains run each day in the south west of England.Passengers have been warned that only around half of services will run, including those to and from London Waterloo, the countrys busiest railway station.The strike will take place every day except the day of the general election on December , with trains also not running on Christmas Day and Boxing Day.A statement from SWR said: RMT strike starts today and we will be running an amended timetable until the New Year.Peak services will be busier than normal and there may be queues at stations so please plan your journey in advance.An SWR emergency timetable shows , out of , weekday trains are due to run.SWR trains run between London Waterloo and Portsmouth, Southampton, Bournemouth, Weymouth, Reading, Exeter and Bristol.It also operates lines in Surrey, Berkshire, and Hampshire.Commuters hit back at todays strike on social media as they battled into work during rush hour.BBC Journalism Researcher Charlotte Baker tweeted: Scenes on the train - nearly got crushed against a metal pole.Feel it’s only a matter of time before someone is hurt.One SWR commuter wrote: Here begins my South Western Rail advent calendar of moans.On the first day of train strikes my true love gave to me, a giant commuter game of sardines.And another posted: Day  of the SWR strikes and it’s nice and busy on the : from Woking to Waterloo.One person has fainted already from the overcrowding. title: who was saskia jones london bridge
story: Heres everything we know about the inspirational -year-old who lived le to the full.Saskia Jones was a -year-old Cambridge grad from Stratford-upon-Avon.In  she graduated from Anglia Ruskin University with a degree in Psychology and Criminology before going on to complete a Masters at Cambridge University.At the time of her death she was working as a personal trainer, but she had plans to join West Midlands Police “with a view to specialising in case management and victim support’’.Saskia was passionate about stopping violence against women and girls and carried out extensive research on the subject.Dr Olivia Smith, one of her Anglia Ruskin lecturers, said: “Saskia Jones was one of those students that makes you so proud to be in this job.I’m so sorry that the world won’t get to see what she could have achieved. She was one of a kind and loved justice. She would have been a force for good and I’m so sorry for us all that we’ve lost her.“Saskia’s dissertation was so good that I cried with pride when I marked it.”On November ,  terrorist, Usman Khan stabbed Saskia Jones in a rampage at Fishmongers Hall on the north side of the river.Saskia and another victim, Jack Merritt, tragically lost their lives.Paying tribute, Saskias family said she was a funny, kind, positive influence at the centre of many peoples lives.She had a wonderful sense of mischievous fun and was generous to the point of always wanting to see the best in all people.She was intent on living le to the full and had a wonderful thirst for knowledge, enabling her to be the best she could be.Saskia had a great passion for providing invaluable support to victims of criminal injustice, which led her to the point of recently applying for the police graduate recruitment programme, wishing to specialise in victim support.This is an extremely painful time for the family. Saskia will leave a huge void in our lives.On a previous post on her Facebook, Saskia had written: I hope when Im gone, someone picks my soul up and thinks, I would have loved her.. - The attacker, Usman Khan, , from Staffordshire, storms into Fishmonger Hall and begins wildly stabbing people.. - Terried onlookers begin calling police after chaos breaks out.. - Six heroes - armed with a fire extinguisher and a narwhals tusk - chase the attacker.. -  The heroic group tackle the attacker, and successfully disarm him.. - Police arrive at the scene. title: moment revellers pirate fairground ride thailand
story: Fourteen people were on the pirate-themed ride at an event in the city of Lopburi in central Thailand when the incident occurred on Saturday night.The ride was at the peak of its height when a bar holding six people in place opened.Five people, two of them children, were then thrown to the floor as the mechanical arm completed its rotation.Four slammed into the rides steel walkway, while one boy was thrown over a steel railing to the ground.He is seen getting to his feet and dusting himself off.He is visibly shaken and has blood coming from a wound to his head, though otherwise does not appear to have sustained serious injuries.A girl can also be heard crying in the background.Paramedics attended the scene and took a number of wounded people to a nearby hospital.Reports said a -year-old girl was found to have suffered a broken leg, though she has now been released.The incident occurred at around pm local time.One witness, named as Jidapa, said: I was taking my young relatives to the fair and watching this ride because it looked so scary.I just heard people screaming at the top then they fell out when the ride came down.Im very shaken by it, too. Ive never seen this happen before.Police today closed the ride down.The man who was operating the ride at the time of the accident, a -year-old name as Ake, apologised for his carelessness in not ensuring the bar was secured.I was in charge at the control centre because my friend who also ran station went to the toilet and then had a break, he said.I want to apologise to the people who were hurt and their family but I did not know much about the machine so I did not check anything before I started it.Police Major General Natthapol Sukrasorn said that he had ordered the machine temporarily closed while checks are carried out on the owners license.We talked to the machine owner and asked them to hand their licenses in to the station so we can  checkthey are legal.We also assigned engineers to check the condition of the mechanics on the ride.They will investigate the ride to seeit had a good standard of safety.If the licenses for the ride were legally registered, the owners will be allowed to continue running the business, butthey were not, we will charge them.Officers also warned the rides owner could face prosecution as well as legal action by those who were injured.

title: nato summit 2019 watford where when road closures
story: But what will happen to public le while this all goes on  Heres everything we know.The NATO  summit will take place in Watford, Herts.Some  of the worlds most important leaders will meet at The Grove Hotel at Chandlers Cross.NATO summits are a periodic opportunity for Heads of State and Heads of Government to meet and evaluate NATOs current strategies, evaluate the alliances current position and brainstorm strategic direction.The main event will take place on Wednesday, December .However, separate events will take place beforehand on December .Before the NATO leaders meeting chaired by the NATO Secretary General at the Grove Hotel, an evening event will take place at Buckingham Palace - thats on December .The summits main event is the NATO leaders meeting.The alliance includes  member states, with countries including Germany, Spain, Greece and Turkey joining, and represents a population of more than  million people.The organisation is considered to be the largest and most powerful military alliance in history.Attending the meeting in Hertfordshire will be Donald Trump, who is visiting the UK during the first week of December.According to the BBC: President Trump will have separate talks with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Emmanuel Macron and Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg and attend a working lunch with representatives from Estonia, Greece, Latvia, Poland, Romania, Lithuania, Bulgaria, and the United Kingdom.The summit will see heightened security, road closures and traffic - title: norovirus flu spread offices snacks desk
story: But as temperatures plummet there are steps we can all take to avoid a bout of norovirus or flu, experts say.One of the first places to start, is at work, says Boots pharmacist Janky Raja.She warned winter bugs can rampage through officesbasic hygiene measures are put in place.Top of the list of things to watch out for are office snacks, communal mugs and dirty keyboards.Janky says: From coughs and colds to norovirus and flu, there’s a whole host of bugs in the air over the winter months and as some health problems can be triggered or worsened by cold weather, now is the time to take steps to help prevent the office bugs.Here, she shares her tips to avoid being struck by a nasty bug in the run up to Christmas...With Christmas just round the corner, everyones offices are quickly filling up with festive snacks.However, Janky says that indulging in these treats can increase your risk of getting winter bugs.She says: Avoid office snacks, not only will passing up on the team’s festive treats reduce your sugar intake butsomeone who is ill has touched the food it can become contaminated.The immune system also relies on a healthy diet to provide the nutrients it needs for optimum , so eating a balanced, ied diet really does go a long way.Make sure the foods you eat are rich in vitamins such as vitamin B, B, C, and D and minerals such as zinc and folic acid, which all work to support your immune system ensuring it works the best it can.We all need a tea-round or cup of coffee to keep up going throughout a busy day of work.But it might be about time you start using your own mug and kitchen utensils - rather than sharing with colleagues.Pharmacist Janky says shared cups and cutlery are covered in germs - and one of the main ways bugs like flu and norovirus spread.She urges: Use your own mugs and cutlery and avoid sharing with colleagues.. Clean surfacesClean surfaces including toilet handles, taps and door handles regularly with disinfectant.. Steer clear of othersAvoid close contact with other people who are sick, or coughing and sneezing a lot.. Wash fruits and cook seafood thoroughlyCarefully wash fruits and vegetables before preparing and eating them and make sure oysters and other shellfish are cooked thoroughly.. Wash laundry wellTry to wash items of clothing with detergent at the maximum available cycleand machine dry themyou can.Research has found that  per cent of office mugs are covered in germs, so rather than using one from the office kitchen, try bringing your own one in and take it home each day to wash properly.Weve all witnessed a colleague leave the bathroom without washing their hands.And it turns out that gross decision may be the reason people in the your office are picking up things like the flu and norovirus.Janky says: Something that is often overlooked is simply to wash your hands regularly, as it helps kill germs.Don’t just wash them after using the toilet, instead make sure you wash them with warm water and soap throughout the day and particularly before eating or after using communal areas.If you look down at your office desk, youll probably notice it doesnt look as spotless as it should do.In fact, dirty desks harbour  times more germs than a toilet seat - which can quickly spread among staff and cause an outbreak of sickness.A study of desks by office supplies firm Viking recently found germs in almost two-thirds of computer keyboards, while some even had mould growing underneath.Phones and desks also had germs, Viking found after analysing swabs sent in by hundreds of office workers.The average desktop harbours , germs per square inch in addition to , on the keyboard and , on a mouse and a staggering , on the phone - far more  germs per inch found on a toilet seat.Janky recommends:It’s worth investing in some antibacterial wipes to clean your desk, keyboard, mouse and phone.If youre too tired youll become much more susceptible to picking up winter bugs.Janky says: Rest is so important and making sure you’re getting enough hours of sleep a night can help reduce daily stress levels and strengthen your immune system.Allowing yourself to become run down means your body isn’t as capable of fighting off infection, so there’s no excuse to not put your feet up and relax.In order to maximise your chances of not getting the flu, doctors are urging people to get vaccinated against the flu virus.Janky says: Get vaccinated against the flu virus as it is the most effective step you can take.Children aged two and three years will be given the vaccine at their general practice - usually by the practice nurse.Young kids in school years one to three are likely to receive their vaccine at school.Pregnant women and anyone aged  and older are also eligible for a free jab.People with long-term heart or respiratory diseases or weakened immune systems will also get a free jab.The vaccine for the over-s has an extra ingredient to boost immune systems.A jab which protects against four rather than three strains will be given to others at risk.Soyoure not in the above groups you can pay for a flu jab at certain stores.Superdrug is offering jabs at £. for non-members.Lloyds Pharmacy is also offering the vaccine fo £. - and you dont have to make an appointment.Boots, Tesco, Asda and Sainsburys all offer jabs which can cost up to £.If you’re entitled to a free NHS flu jab this can be administered at your local Boots pharmacy in England and Wales, as well as through your GP.People living in Scotland and Northern Ireland can,eligible, get the free NHS flu jab through their GP.Customers aged  years and above can also access the private Boots Winter Flu Jab Service.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRosie Marcel is dressed in navy hospital scrubs and trainers – the practical kind you might actually go for a run in, not the trendy kind – and her trademark strawberry-blonde locks are pulled into in a messy bun. If she looks exactly like Holby City’s uptight heart consultant Jac Naylor – the character she’s played for the past  years – it’s because she’s stepped straight off the set and into BBC Elstree’s scruffy backstage green room meeting us between scenes. Thankfully, unlike the frosty-faced, hard-as-nails doc who viewers have grown to love, the real Rosie is warm and open, greeting us with a hug. She sips from a water bottle and has one of those immaculate complexions that suggests she downs two litres of the stuff a day. ‘I can assure you I don’t,’ laughs the actor, who lives with second husband Ben Stacey, a gym owner, their five-year-old daughter, Beau, and their four dogs in St Albans. ‘I’m wearing a lot of make-up! I haven’t resorted to Botox yet, but I’m looking forward to it!’ Settling down on the sofa for a natter, Rosie explains how filming Jac’s harrowing nervous breakdown scene, which airs this week, was traumatic because it mirrored her own le three years ago, when she crashed out with depression, anxiety and depersonalisation disorder. Given your mental health struggles, was it emotional, acting Jac’s breakdown  It was the hardest thing I’ve done in my le. When I was first approached about the storyline, I wasn’t happy at all. In fact, I was frightened. But after a lot of cajoling from my agent and the producers, and talking with my husband, I decided it was an important story to tell on behalf of other working mothers. Can you tell us about your own breakdown  Like many first-time mums, I was overwhelmed. Six months after having a baby by C-section, I ed to working long days and I wasn’t being healthy. Scripts were coming in very late and none of what I was reading made sense. One day, I just lost it and shouted at people that they were stopping me from seeing my kid and having a le. A director marched me off set, I called my doctor and I was signed off work immediately.  What were you eventually diagnosed with  Stress, anxiety and depersonalisation disorder – that means you don’t feel like you’re in your own body, you don’t recognise yourself. I remember going home, getting into my pyjamas and looking down on myself asfrom a dferent part of the room. In that moment, I decided everyone would be better off without me. I walked out of the house, without my phone or anything, with no intention of coming back. I turned up at my friend’s house having no idea how I got there. It was pretty scary. How did you get better  I found a therapist. I was reluctant at first because, in all honesty, I saw it as a sign of weakness. My siblings and I were all brought up to be strong iniduals. My mother left when I was very young and we learnt to look after ourselves. I’m a very strong person on the outside. But that all caught up with me.  It’s brave to open up, though... I don’t like people to see I’m vulnerable, but by putting my struggles out there, I hope to help people. All the comments I’ve received have been positive, which is rewarding. Let’s face it, the rest of what I do is just telly, isn’t it  I spent a lot of my childhood wanting people to like me. But I’ve given up on that –you don’t like me that’s fine. I’m  and I finally like myself. How much of your own experience did you bring to your breakdown scenes  Everything. I had a say in the scripts and was allowed a day a week for therapy. I absolutely needed to talk it out, after putting myself back in a vulnerable position. I found it very distressing, watching the scene back where Jac totally loses it in front of her daughter and needs restraining, as did my husband. I still get anxiety about it. I was in a really tired, dark place at the end of filming, so I took three weeks off. I slept a lot and did normal things: I took my kid to school, I walked my dogs, I cleaned my house, I cooked for my family – all the things I really enjoy. If I weren’t at Holby, I would absolutely be a housewe!  How do you stay mentally strong now  Therapy will always be part of my le. I’m lucky enough to be able to afford it. I meditate for  minutes every day and haven’t drunk alcohol in two years. I really miss a lovely glass of red wine, but it’s not good for my mental health. How are your other health issues  You’ve battled endometriosis, haemophilia, the inflammatory disease Behcet’s, and cervical cancer  I’m a bit of a mess, aren’t I  I’ll be on immunosuppressants my whole le. I do feel terribly sorry for myself some days and I sit and cry, but I pick myself up. I’ve got a strong personality and, as an ill person, I don’t like to be told I can’t do things. I enjoy a challenge – I’d love to do something like … and would be horribly competitive. But I’m such an animal lover, I’m not sure how I would manage eating kangaroo balls!    Is Ben very supportive  He knows me better than anyone  and has seen parts of me no one  has. He’s seen me walk out in the middle of the night and not come back, and seen me not being safe to be around my daughter – not that I would ever have been a risk to her, but I was just in such a bad place. And he’s the person who says to me, ‘You need to see your therapist.’ He spots it in me before I do. He’s very good. I know when he’s stressed because he throws himself into a workout.  Do people sometimes think you’re a real doctor  My grandmother would often show me a mark on her arm, asking, ‘What do you think it is ’ I’d keep telling her, ‘I don’t know. I’m not actually a doctor.’ Once a girl fainted right in front of me and someone shouted, ‘Help her!’ and I shouted back, ‘I don’t know what I’m doing!’ What’s the weirdest place you’ve been asked for a selfie  Disneyland. I posed wearing a pair of Mickey Mouse ears, embarrassing! How will you spend Christmas this year  We have friends coming – we’re godparents to their children – and I’ll cook. I can’t stand turkey – it’s too dry for me – so I’ll do a chicken and a proper glazed ham with Yorkshire puds.  The tree won’t last five minutes as we have four dogs – it’ll be chaos! Last year, I went a bit OTT with gts and Beau said halfway through the present-opening, ‘I don’t want to open any more’. I love watching old films with her – Annie, Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Elf. Then I’ll take the leftover ham to enjoy with my sister on Boxing Day – she’s over from LA.

title: jeremy corbyn says spending plans
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn says spending plans will rebalance  years of Tory austerityThe Labour leader said his spending pledges would correct the fall in living standards and the damage caused to public services over the past decade under the ConservativesShareCommentsByElaine McCahillDeputy News Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsJeremy Corbyn has said Labours spending plans with rebalance a decade of Tory austerity "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn has said his spending pledges will correct  years of Tory austerity.The Labour leader said peopleaposs quality of le had declined while public services had suffered under successive Conservative governments. It comes as he pledged to slash regulated rail fares in England by a third from next month.Labour intends to bring the railways back into public ownershipthe party wins the December  election and then cut regulated rail fares by % from January . The party estimates the policy would save the average commuter more than £, a year, in what it described as the biggest ever reduction in rail fares. The policy came as hundreds of thousands of passengers on South Western Railway were facing travel misery on Monday at the start of a -day strike in the long-running dispute over guards on trains. And it came after the UKaposs train companies confirmed over the weekend that they will hike prices by an average of .% next year. Children aged  and under would receive free rail travel under Labouraposs plans, while part-time workers would be guaranteed fair fares. Mr Corbyn officially launched the policy outside Londonaposs Finsbury Park station in the Islington North constituency he has held since . They are not giveaways, they are rebalancing what we had, which was  years of austerity in which living standards have often fallen, income levels have been static, and in some cases fallen, and public services have been damaged and reduced, he told reporters. Andall of our spending commitments, the whole of our manesto, is carried out to every last letter we still barely reach the levels of public services of France or Germany and thataposs how far behind weaposve fallen because of the strategy thataposs been followed. The cold Monday morning saw Mr Corbyn receive a warm reception from both activists and constituents as he was lavished with praise, offers of good luck and posed for multiple selfies, including with rail workers.  His party has also pledged to deliver a simple, London-style ticketing system across the nation - with islands within which zonal rail fares will apply across all modes of public transport.There would be a daily price cap so travellers can pay as they go using bank cards or mobile phones.Labour estimates that the policy will cost £. billion per year and would come from existing Department for Transport budgets, drawn from Vehicle Excise Duty, commonly known as road tax.

title: labour poll surge after blasting
story: NewsLabour poll surge after blasting Tory cuts that make UK vulnerable to terrorJeremy Corbyn today vowed “you can’t keep people safe on the cheap” after terrorist Usman Khan killed Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones on London Bridge after being released early from jailShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  DEC NewsLabour leader Jeremy Corbyn in Whitby on the general election campaign trail"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyn blasted Tory cuts that have left the country vulnerable to terrorism as Labour surged in the polls with vows to end austerity.The Labour leader also slammed the part-privatisation of the probation service as he spoke out in the wake of Friday’s London Bridge atrocity – which he called an attack on “our democratic process itself”. Terrorist Usman Khan killed Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones after being released early from jail on licence. Mr Corbyn warned cuts to the justice system can lead to “missed chances to intervene in the lives of people who go on to commit absolutely inexcusable acts”. He said: “You can’t keep people safe on the cheap.” He was backed by criminologist and former prison officer Ian Acheson, who led a government review of Islamist extremism in prisons and probation. Mr Acheson said: “At the heart of this is the destruction of the prison and probation service through crazy, failed, ideological austerity cuts.” Mr Corbyn also highlighted police cuts that have led to the loss of , officers since . He said: “No government can prevent every attack but it can act to make such acts of terror less rather than more likely. Public services are the glue that binds our society to­­gether – community pol­­icing, the probation service, mental health, youth and social services... When those public services are cut back they leave behind gaps.” He vowed to “do whatever is necessary and effective to keep our people safe”. Mr Corbyn, who opposed UK military action in Iraq, Afghanistan and Libya, also accused successive British governments – including New Labour – of fuelling the terror threat by waging war abroad. He said: “Their mistakes in no way absolve terrorists of blame for their murderous actions – the blame lies with the terrorists, their funders and recruiters. Butwe are to protect people, we must be honest about what threatens our security. Too often the actions of successive governments have fuelled, not reduced, that threat.”  He also lashed the government for failing to release a report into Saudi funding of extremist groups. He said: “Given Friday’s events and the continuing terror threat, it is simply unacceptable that this report is not in the public domain.” He vowed to “stop arms sales to Saudi Arabia for use in Yemen” and again pledged to introduce a War Powers Bill so a prime minister would have to win Parliament’s support for any military action. He was speaking in York on the election trail in North Yorkshire, where he was snapped in Whitby wearing a jacket with the words “for the many not the few” woven into the pinstripe. Mr Corbyn was given a polls boost as several surveys showed the gap narrowing between Labour and the Conservatives.

title: tories could lose safe seat
story: NewsTories could lose safe seat after  years as Hugh Grant begs voters to oust themEast Devon is tipped to change hands, with Conservatives nervous about losing it and the Love Actually actor is urging voters to back independent candidate Claire WrightShareCommentsByDaniel Clark:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsIndependent Claire Wright is hoping to end more than  years of Tory control in East Devon "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories could be ousted from a seat theyaposve held for more than  years next week - with an independent candidate hoping to pulling off a historic win. Claire Wright is tipped by some to win in East Devon, a seat that has traditionally been a safe Conservative constituency. Love Actually star Hugh Grant has urged Labour , Lib Dem and Green voters to back Ms Wright. It comes after the MRP YouGov poll, released last week, said East Devon is likely to elect an Independent. It would be a major blow to the Conservativesthey lose the seat. Ms Wright, who has stood twice before, has seen her share of the vote rise from % in  to % in , and is eyeing up a place in Parliament. It will be an interesting battleground, Devon Live reports , as the Tories lost their district council majority in May after  years. It is now run as a minority administration by Independents. Their poll had Claire Wright on % of the vote, and ranging between % and % - just six points behind Tory candidate Simon Jupp. Ms Wright, , said: “The past few years have demonstrated that the party system is broken. “It is time for change. As an Independent, I would have exactly the same rights as other MPs and would work cross-party to achieve my manesto pledges. “I am dferent. I have no party whip to tell me how to vote. I am free to speak and free to act. And free to fight for the issues that the people of East Devon care about the most. “This election is very unpredictable and presents a rare opportunity for residents to elect an MP who truly cares and puts them first.” Former broadcaster Mr Jupp, , thinks dferently. He said: “I was expecting it to be a bit more dficult and to face a lot of opposition but people just saying to me that they want to get on with it. “I know it is what you would expect me to say, but people are telling me that they want to get Brexit done. I voted to remain, but I back Boris’s Brexit deal, it’s a fantastic deal for this country to move forward. Clearly anxious about losing the seat, both Boris Johnson and Health Secretary Matt Hancock have visited the constituency in recent weeks.  Mr Jupp said: “This may traditionally be a safe seat but it is not a safe seat this time around and we will have to fight to win it. “The Conservatives struggled earlier this year, but it is safe to say that the Tory party is in a very dferent position than it was the district council and EU elections. Speaking after a hustings event on Thursday night, Ms Wright said: Political parties should be judged on their records – ten years of grinding austerity in this case. East Devon voters should not be fooled by late apologies and hollow promises when election time comes around. “When faced by the public, the local candidate attempts to position himself as a campaigner against the same cuts over which his party has presided – it just won’t wash. The party pays lip service to the NHS. Actions always speak louder than words.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn her own words, Chris Martinaposs sister Nicola Wren explains how it felt to grow up with a famous sibling... When I was a kid, I was convinced I was going to be a star, because I was always told I was good in the village productions. And why wouldn’t I be a star  I was  years old, and my brother Chris, then , had been considered talented too, and look what he’d achieved. He was in Coldplay. And really, really famous. I’m the youngest and Chris is the oldest. Our second-oldest brother, Al, is an architect, our sister, Rosie, is a nurse and our other brother, Richard, is in the Army. I’m an actor and my parents say all their children are ‘working towards their potential’. I have two side jobs too, just to keep a bit of money coming in: I’m a kids’-party entertainer and transcribe interviews for people. Of course, my surname is Martin, but I changed it to Wren – after a Pizza Express pizza I’m fond of – when I started acting. There was another Nicola Martin on the acting directory, and I also had this fear people would think, ‘Oh, it’ll be easy for her – Chris can get her work.’ I wanted to do it for myself. As the youngest of five kids, all I ever wanted was for my siblings to think I was fab at everything I did. That’s maybe why I secretly want to be a bit famous – it’s love and validation. But anyone with lots of siblings will know what it feels like to grow up in someone’s shadow, Coldplay or no Coldplay.  There’s always a favourite – although I don’t actually think Chris is the favourite in our family! Growing up, I knew he was talented and, because we had the biggest age gap, there was less rivalry between us. He’d make up silly songs about me and my pet gerbils, and send me funny postcards when he went away. He was my hero and I just absolutely adored him. I was eight when Coldplay got together, and  when Chris met Gwyneth Paltrow. That’s when things got a lot bigger for him.  I was doing quite a bit of acting and thought I was the big cheese of the village. I’d landed the part of Mole in The Wind In The Willows and believed it was my big moment. I was peeping through the curtain and, just as the show started, I saw two people sneak in wearing caps. I realised it was Chris, with this woman I’d met a few weeks earlier backstage at a Coldplay concert. I remember other people being really excited, but the name Gwyneth Paltrow meant nothing to me at my age. I didn’t know she’d appeared in Shakespeare In Love and I genuinely thought, ‘Yeah, she acts, but I bet she never played Mole.’  After the show, I ran backstage, ready for my praise and Chris and Gwyneth were there, surrounded by people, with everyone wanting photos and autographs. I was really confused – why didn’t anyone want my autograph ! In hindsight, I realise that was when I changed from being the deluded little girl who thought she was a huge star to being seen as Chris Martin’s little sister. When Coldplay first started getting big, Chris would say to me, ‘Let’s go out and get recognised!’ It was a fun game we liked to play because it was only ever fans of the band and only a few people. But when Gwyneth arrived it was a totally dferent type of recognition. Paparazzi would wait outside our house and hide in our garden. That wasn’t very nice.  My parents explained I wasn’t to speak to them as they were sneaky. That’s when I realised I didn’t really know who to trust and I started not wanting people knowing Chris was my brother. Chris and Gwyneth lived in London together, but they’d come to the village for Christmas. After my niece, Apple, was born, the press would be waiting outside trying to get a glimpse. Although I wanted to be an actor, I didn’t see Gwyneth as a big star. All I cared about was that she was my brother’s cool girlfriend who showed me affection and was so kind to me. She was awesome. I went to boarding school a year after they met and I tried not to tell anyone Chris was my brother.  Only I was so homesick, she called and spoke to me every single day. We were really close and especially as a younger sister, when your older brother has a cool girlfriend, you love them. I remember in Home Economics we were making woolly hats and I made two. One for Gwyneth and one for my other brother’s girlfriend at the time. I gave it to Gwyneth and remember thinking, ‘I bet she’s going to get papped wearing that hat.’ I never saw her wear it! It was a shit hat, but I’d done her favourite colours. She was very appreciative and sweet when I gave it to her though. Despite the mega-fame in Chris’s le, the rest of the family all lived normally.  I graduated from drama school and went over to LA to visit him. Gwyneth said she’d take me to the Golden Globes. She helped me pick a dress and get ready, and that was the first time I thought, ‘This is absolutely mental.’ There were brilliant actors all around me and I was thinking, ‘When I get home, I’m back to working in a pub.’ People assume I have a lavish lestyle and Chris bankrolls me, but I’d never ask him for anything – he has his own family. We were always taught the value of money. I needed a new bike recently and some friends said, ‘Can’t Chris pay for it ’ No. It’s nice to save up and buy things yourself. But I’m fortunate thatI was down on my luck, I have people who can help.  My dating le has been tricky with a famous brother. A boy dumped me because he was in a band and was worried people would think he was using me to get to Chris. That was really hard for  him , apparently! I broke up with someone recently in the pub and my brother’s song  The Hardest Part  was playing. And, sometimes, I’ll beon a date, snogging, and a Coldplay song will come on. It’s too weird! Of course, there’s part of me that loves it, becausesomeone dumps me, at least they’ll think about me loads afterwards because they’ll hear Coldplay wherever they go!  I used to pretend I hated the band, as I thought that was cooler, but I’m not afraid to admit I love them now. Their music gives me great comfort and I like taking my friends to their gigs, as they’re brilliant live.

story: NewsCampaign boy survived worst case of childhood cancer doctor has ever seenRyan Savage was just three when medics warned his parents that he could have as little as two months to live after he was diagnosed with stage four neuroblastomaShareCommentsByNaomi CorriganLorraine King:,  DEC NewsRyan was just three when he was first diagnosed with cancer"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager beat the odds to survive aposthe worst case of cancerapos a doctor had ever seen. Ryan Savage, , was just three when medics warned his parents that he could have as little as two months to live. Following an MRI scan in October , he had been diagnosed with rare childhood cancer neuroblastoma and it was stage four - the most serious. Doctors found a tumour wrapped around Ryanaposs spine and his horried parents were told that his survival rate was just %. Ryan, from Billingham, County Durham, features in a charity Christmas campaign for Neuroblastoma UK and his family hopes his story can raise vital funds for research into the childhood cancer and support others facing the same terrying battle. His mum Lisa said: This year will be the tenth Christmas we’ll have with Ryan that, at one time, I never ever thought we’d have. Every time Christmas comes around, itaposs a precious reminder to our family that another year has passed since Ryan fought this terrible disease twice, and won. My son is my hero, my warrior, my survivor and my inspiration. We don’t know what the future will hold, but he beat neuroblastoma twice, against all the odds. “More funding is needed to invest in research and give more families like mine hope.”  Following Ryanaposs diagnosis he was forced to endure a gruelling year of cancer treatment beginning with immediate chemotherapy followed by surgery to remove the majority of the tumours. Afterwards he was in remission. Our world was turned upside-down by a cancer we had never even heard of before, said Lisa. But two years later, doctors found another tumour in his chest and the consultant said it was the worst case that sheaposd ever seen.  The brave youngster again fought against the odds, undergoing years of gruelling chemotherapy and surgeries before Ryan, Lisa, his dad Tim and sister Annie were given the news the cancer had gone. Seeing what Ryan went through, it breaks my heart to think of all those children fighting neuroblastoma this Christmas, said Lisa. Little children simply donapost deserve to be robbed of their precious early years, nor should they have the threat of their cancer ing constantly hanging over them. But there is still so much more research that needs to be done to prevent children suffering like Ryan did.  The Christmas campaign by Neuroblastoma aims to #GiveHope to families like Ryanaposs, by raising money for leading research projects which aim to deliver new, more effective and kinder treatments for children with neuroblastoma. Katherine Mobey, fundraising manager at Neuroblastoma UK said: With our new fundraising campaign, we want to give hope to more families like Ryanaposs.

story: NewsFamous royal facial trait down to inbreeding - but Charles II sorted it outThe Habsburgs, once the rulers of Europe, were renowned for their protruding jaws. Researchers claim the notorious chin was the result of inbreeding, which ultimately led to the decline of the royal householdShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  DEC NewsKing Charles II of Spain was renowned for his jaw"Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe protruding aposHabsburg jawapos - a physical feature closely associated with the now-extinct royal household - was the result of inbreeding, a new study claims. Generations of intermarriage secured the Habsburg dynastyaposs dominance over a vast European empire encompassing Austria and Spain for more than two centuries. However it also led to its decline when Charles II, the final Habsburg monarch, was unable to produce an heir. Until now, no research has been able to confirm that the Habsburgsapos distinct chin was a result of inbreeding. Study leader Professor Roman Vilas said: The Habsburg dynasty was one of the most influential in Europe, but became renowned for inbreeding, which was its eventual downfall. We show for the first time that there is a clear positive relationship between inbreeding and appearance of the Habsburg jaw. The researchers recruited ten specialist facial surgeons to identy the Habsburg jaw in  portraits of  members of the dynasty. Despite dferences in artistic style, the portraits are characterised by a realistic approach to the human face. The surgeons were asked to diagnose eleven features of the Habsburg Jaw - or mandibular prognathism - as well as seven features of maxillary deficiency, the most recognisable of which are a prominent lower lip and an overhanging nasal tip. The portraits are hanging in some of the most prominent art museums in the world, including the KunsthistorischesMuseum in Vienna and the Prado in Madrid. The surgeons gave scores for the degree of mandibular prognathism and maxillary deficiency in each member of the Habsburg family. Mary of Burgundy, who married into the family in , showed the least degree of both traits. The Habsburg jaw was most pronounced in Philip IV, King of Spain and Portugal from  to . Maxillary deficiency was diagnosed to the greatest degree in five members of the family: Maximilian I , his daughter Margaret of Austria, his nephew Charles I of Spain, Charlesapos great-grandson Philip IV and the last in the Habsburg line, Charles II. Detecting a correlation between the two conditions, the researchers speculated that they share a genetic basis. The extent of inbreeding was calculated from a large-scale family tree, including more than , iniduals belonging to more than  generations. The researchers detected a strong relationship between the degree of inbreeding and the extent of the Habsburg jaw. The relationship to maxillary deficiency was also positive, but it was only statistically signicant in two of the seven features diagnosed.

Former University of Cambridge students Saskia, , and Jack, , were stabbed to death by -year-old convicted terrorist Usman Khan during a prisoner rehabilitation event they were both supporting. Leanne OaposBrien was pictured arriving at the vigil in floods of tears.Dressed in black jeans and black jacket, she appeared distraught and clutched a pink, soft toy in her hands. She was supported and comforted by the parents of boyfriend Jack during the event. At the same time Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn were at the remembrance service at Guildhall Yard in the capital. A book of condolences has been opened at Guildhall Art Gallery, and members of the public have been invited to lay flowers outside nearby Mansion House. The service in London was less than a mile from Fishmongersapos Hall, where Khan launched his attack on Friday. An attack on any one of us is an attack on us all. Haters are not welcome. We are London and we wonapost fall.apos Khan, , from Stoke, was on licence and wearing an electronic monitoring tag when he launched the attack, which injured three others, after he was invited to the prisoner rehabilitation conference on Friday afternoon. The event was organised held by Learning Together, a programme associated with Cambridge Universityaposs Institute of Criminology. The attack has prompted the Ministry of Justice to review the licence conditions of every convicted terrorist released from prison, which Prime Minister Boris Johnson said was probably about  people.Mr Johnson has vowed to take steps to ensure people are not released early when they commit serious offences. But the family of Mr Merritt, from Cottenham, Cambridgeshire, asked for his death to not to be used to justy introducing even more draconian sentences on offenders in a heartfelt tribute released on Sunday. We know Jack would not want this terrible, isolated incident to be used as a pretext by the government for introducing even more draconian sentences on prisoners, or for detaining people in prison for longer than necessary. And in a tweet on Sunday evening, Mr Merrittaposs father David said: Donapost use my sonaposs death, and his and his colleagueaposs photos - to promote your vile propaganda. Jack stood against everything you stand for - hatred, ision, ignorance. In a statement, they said: She was intent on living le to the full and had a wonderful thirst for knowledge, enabling her to be the best she could be. Saskia had a great passion for providing invaluable support to victims of criminal injustice, which led her to the point of recently applying for the police graduate recruitment programme, wishing to specialise in victim support.  Khan, who was living in Stafford, was given permission to travel into the heart of London by police and the Probation Service. Convicted of terror offences in February , he was released from prison on licence in December , halfway through his -year prison sentence. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJust weeks before Christmas, when most other girls of her age were dreaming of what Santa might leave under the tree, eight-year-old Courtney went to a foodbank with her mum for the first time. Little Courtney had been forced to understand the meaning of money – and how it feels to live without it. Hungry and cold, instead of enjoying a carefree childhood she worried about how her family would survive. She says: “Sometimes we slept in our coats because we couldn’t afford the heating. Mum sometimes didn’t have any dinner so me and my brother could eat ours. Or we would go to the foodbank to get food. “It was scary sometimes because I was worrying about money. It would worry me at school, and I wanted to make it better for my mum.” Mum Charlotte had fled abuse and was housed in a three-bedroom flat in Cambridge – one of the most expensive cities in the UK – with Courtney and her brother Nathaniel James, six. Out of work after being diagnosed with a serious mental health condition, the mum-of-two faced a five-week wait for Universal Credit and says she had to live on just £-a-day child benefit. Are you a struggling parent  Email webnews@mirror To add insult to injury, she had to find the money to pay bedroom tax – meaning there was little left to feed her young children or keep them warm. Charlotte, , says: “I felt like I was living in third world country, I had so little money. I had to make tough choices between paying to heat the flat, or buying food for the kids. “I’d get down to my last few pence and have nowhere to turn. Sometimes I’d go without food to make sure the kids ate – they always came first. “A lot of people are just one crisis away from living below the breadline. “We were OK before I had to move. The flat in Cambridge had three bedrooms, and I was told my children should be sharing a room, so had to pay an extra £ in bedroom tax. I had to take a loan out to pay for food for Christmas and to pay my rent and bills. I got behind on rent while waiting for my first Universal Credit payment. We had nothing. It was hell.”  That first time at the foodbank, hungry and confused, little Courtney didn’t even know what the place was. She says: “I thought a foodbank is where food came out of a bank – like a hole in the wall where money comes out, but with food in it. It was really weird being there – I didn’t like it. I can’t always get what I want to eat, because Mum doesn’t have that kind of money. But that day I got Pringles and biscuits. I went back there a few times with my mum.” Courtney is one of the . million children growing up in poverty in the UK, where one in three youngsters are living below the breadline. That is are why we are today asking readers to Give Kids a Cracking Christmas as we launch our Christmas appeal for charity Action for Children. Child poverty will surge to a -year highthe Conservatives remain in power, an influential think-tank says. And the country’s biggest foodbank charity, the Trussell Trust, is bracing itself for its busiest December ever, after distributing , emergency food parcels to children last Christmas. Courtney and her family were eventually forced to move to Hull, where Charlotte was able to save more than £-a-month in rent – vital money she needed for food and bills.

The Duke of York, , lives in the -room Royal Lodge in Windsor, which he agreed a -year lease on in  after making a one-off payment of £million to the Crown Estate - equating to payment of around £ a week. He was forced to give up frontline royal duties after what has been widely described as a aposcar crashapos interview with BBC presenter Emily Maitlis last month, in which he was grilled over his his friendship with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. title: prince andrew plugged private bank
story: NewsPrince Andrew plugged private bank for millionaire who paid Fergies debtsThere are demands for a parliamentary inquiry after a whistleblower allegedly became so concerned about Andrew’s business dealings they emailed Prince Charles in August to warn himShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorChristopher Bucktin:,  DEC NewsPrince Andrew with King Hamad bin Isa Al Khala of Bahrain"Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Andrew has been plunged deeper into crisis after he was accused of repeatedly exploiting his role as Britain’s trade envoy to help wealthy friends. Critics last night demanded a ­Parliamentary inquiry into claims the Duke of York “plugged a private bank for the super-rich” owned by millionaire financier David “Spotty” Rowland. Mr Rowland, who was a tax exile for decades, once helped clear Sarah ­Ferguson’s debts. It is claimed a whistleblower was so concerned about Andrew’s business dealings they emailed Prince Charles in August to warn him about them. It comes after the duke was forced to step back from frontline duties amid the fallout from his disastrous Newsnight interview about his friendship with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. Labour’s ex-Foreign Office Minister Chris Bryant called for an inquiry into the claims to be carried out by either the Foreign Affairs Committee or the Public Accounts Committee. Speaking to the Mirror, he said: “It should look at the evident conflict of interest when he was travelling at great expense to the taxpayer as a trade envoy but actively pursuing his own financial interests and those of his mates.” It is claimed that during official trade missions on behalf of her Majesty, Andrew, , allegedly promoted his pal’s Luxembourg-based operation as he gained access to the super-rich elite. The prince reportedly let Rowland and his family schedule meetings during official trade tours, so they could court powerful and wealthy clients. In response, Buckingham Palace insisted the duke was promoting British interests “not the interests of iniduals”. Andrew has also been accused of giving the Rowlands sensitive government documents they had no right to see. Leaked emails reveal he demanded a private briefing about the then Labour Government’s attempt to reclaim £.billion owed by Iceland after the collapse of online bank Icesave. Papers drawn up by one of then Chancellor Alistair Darling’s top aides are claimed to have been sent to Mr Rowland by Andrew two hours later with a suggestion he wait before making his “move”.  Only months earlier, the Rowlands had bought a ision of a collapsed Icelandic bank in an £million deal. Andrew also took Spotty’s son, ­ Jonathan, on an official trade mission to Saudi Arabia. There they met Prince Sultan bin Salman bin Abdulaziz al Saud, second son of the country’s current monarch. The duke also had a % stake in a firm in the British Virgin Islands called Inverness Asset Management that existed until March. It is claimed it was used to attract wealthy connections to invest in a tax-free offshore fund. According to the Mail on Sunday, one email shows when Andrew faced the sack from his trade envoy role due to his friendship with Epstein, Jonathan Rowland suggested their commercial activities continue “under the radar”.Andrew replied: “Ilike your thinking”, the paper alleges.Further exchanges with Andrew’s office are said to detail attempts to promote the Rowlands’ business on the duke’s visits to the Middle East and China. On one trip, Andrew reportedly lobbied the King of Bahrain, Hamad bin Isa Al Khala, about the Rowlands’ plans to open an offshoot of their bank in the country.  He later telephoned an official to help get the lucrative venture off the ground, it is alleged. In  Andrew opened Mr Rowland’s bank in Luxembourg in his official capacity. Two years later it was revealed the property tycoon, , had helped pay off some of the Duchess of York’s debts. He is reported to have handed Fergie £,. Epstein separately loaned her £, to pay creditors. In  Mr Rowland caused Prime Minister David Cameron embarrassment when he quit as Tory party treasurer before taking up his post. His appointment to the role had been dogged by criticism over his former status as a tax exile. After he gave £million to the party in , it emerged he had lived in Guernsey for tax purposes but ed to full UK residency to be able to donate to the party legally. Leaked emails from Jonathan Rowland also allege Andrew planned to take a stake in the family’s bank.

story: NewsWomans dream of becoming doctor wrecked in horror hot air ballooning accidentRebecca Fry suffered le changing injuries after the hot air balloon she was in hit power cables before crash-landing in a field in Earls Barton, NorthamptonshireShareByNev Ayling:,  DEC NewsRebecca Fry was electrocuted by , volts "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Rebecca Fry claims she was simultaneously electrocuted, set on fire and shot  feet into the air during a balloon ride after it collided with power cables  feet above the ground. The then -year-old had posed for a selfie moments before the idyllic ride in May  - which was a gt from her fiancee Bret Hay - became a fiery catastrophe. She suffered agonising burns and was airlted to hospital for emergency treatment after the balloon crash-landed in a field in Earls Barton, Northamptonshire. Ms Fry, now , of Northampton, needed four weeks of intensive treatment in a specialist burns unit and required skin grafts to repair her damaged body. As she expects the birth of her first child Ms Fry is suing flight operators The Sackville Balloon Flying Group for more than £million in damages. Reliving the the terror of the mid-air crash, Ms Fry said: The basket burst into flames and the intense heat forced the balloon to shoot up - the heat was making it rise.  I was trying to scream, but I couldnapost open my mouth as the electricity was pressing my teeth together. My leggings were burnt and melted into my body. I thought I was going to die. My body became numb and I thought aposIaposm on fireapos. I could feel electricity going through me and I couldnapost see or hear anything.  I had no control over my body. I was conscious throughout most of it, I felt asmy neck was going to snap. During a pre-trial hearing in Londonaposs High Court Romilly Cummerson, her barrister, spoke about the impact the incident had had on Ms Fry. She is still having dficulties, particularly in respect of her psychiatric injuries, the lawyer said.  The accident occurred at a particularly inopportune moment for her, as she was about to embark on a course that she was hoping would lead to a medical degree. Ms Fry has tried to get back into a health care role as a nurse, but has experienced quite signicant dficulties. Ms Fry claims the accident stalled her hopes of studying to become a doctor, and part of her claim is for loss of future earnings as a medic.  Her claim includes damages for psychiatric trauma and for the impact of the balloon crash on her potential medical career. While they admit liability for her injuries, defence lawyers are disputing the amount of compensation she deserves.
